0.paragraph: The excavation site is located at 123 Main Street, Melbourne, Victoria. It is a busy area with a variety of shops and restaurants nearby. The site itself is relatively small, but it contains a wealth of information that will help researchers better understand the history of the area.

page_content='controlled  and  shallow  scrapes  of  the  mechanical  excavator.  It  was  understood  that  if  any

requirements set out in the Consent. If any artefacts were to be uncovered, Heritage Victoria 

would be informed, and the artefacts would be recorded and collected.

3.5  MONITORING RESULTS 

Trench 1 

Trench  1  was  located  at  the  north  west  of  the  development  footprint.  It  was  a  north-south 

aligned trench that was covered by a dense grass cover (Figure 12). The trench measured' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5181_H7721-0534 120 Russells Road Mt Duneed Archaeological Monitoring Report 22.02.22.pdf'}

page_content='investigate  the  deposit  by  hand  and  record  the  archaeological  remains,  using  a  context-

based system. If significant archaeological deposits, features or artefacts are discovered, an 

expanded  excavation  to  expose  the  full  extent  of  the  features  may  be  necessary,  to  be 

endorsed by the Executive Director, Heritage Victoria. If the deposit is of high significance 

or  is  proving  complex,  Megan  Goulding  must  investigate  the  site  (or  oversees  the 

investigation  while  on-site),  or  an  alternate  archaeologist  as  approved  by  the 

Executive Director, Heritage Victoria at the time of consultation with Heritage Victoria. 

Archaeological monitoring may cease if the archaeologist listed on the Consent believes that

There  are  two  categories  of  listing  provided  for  under  the Heritage  Act  2017;  the  Victorian  Heritage 

Register and the Heritage Inventory. 

The Victorian Heritage Register 

The heritage register is a register of all heritage places, relics, buildings, objects or shipwrecks deemed 

to be of outstanding cultural significance to the State of Victoria. Section 87 of the Heritage Act 2017 

states that it is an offence to knowingly or recklessly remove, relocate or demolish, damage or despoil,' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5181_H7721-0534 120 Russells Road Mt Duneed Archaeological Monitoring Report 22.02.22.pdf'}

1.4 

LEGISLATIVE REQUIREMENTS  

Consent from Heritage Victoria is required to disturb or destroy historical archaeological sites, 

places, buildings or structures listed on the VHI. An application may be made to the Executive 

Director for a Consent to Disturb or Destroy an archaeological site or relic listed on the VHI 

under Section 124.
